answers.author: Paul Shew
answers.text:
It depends.
You did not say how long it has been that you have waited; and what seems long to you may be SOP for the organization.  Consequently you may not want to do anything at the moment.  Overall, it would seem appropriate to abide with the protocol the city originally established.  If the time grows too long, another letter expressing your continued interest might be a good technique to use.  As Dennis Miller says after his rants:  'Icould be wrong.'

answers.text:
I share the same conundrum. What exactly is the protocol about a position with a city of any size when it comes to finding out about a position that you have applied to?
In my case, the largest city I have sought a position in serves roughly one million people and the smallest almost 7,500 people. The positions I have applied to range from low-level manager positions to upper-level manager positions depending upon the written requirements and expectations of the posting.
Any help from people involved with the nuances of Human Resources will be appreciated.

answers.author: Fred Ventresco
answers.text:
I agree with all of the above responses.  However, I would emphasize that if/when you check back that it be with the person/department that you have made contact with (unless ,of course, they have told you to contact another person/department with future inquiries); otherwise, it may look like you are trying to go outside the chain of command/procedures and/or go over somebody’s head.    (Comments, please, if anyone thinks this is not necessary.)

answers.author: Robert Harrison
answers.text:
You may want to consider connecting with the hiring manager on Linked-in.  Also, I think it depends on the size of the City in which you are applying.  The smaller the City, the more likely you could connect with the City Manager.  You may want to reach out and ask for an appointment to discuss breaking into the profession.  The larger the organization, the more formalized it will be, and so you likely have to work through HR.  Again think about how you can build your social network so that when these opportunities come about, you are not a stranger, but have actually started building a relationship with an organization.  Most individuals land position because of social connections.  Good luck to you!

author: [Anonymous]
text:
There is a national recruitment for a management-level employee for a large city. 
The initial review of materials is handled by the city's HR department. 
The materials are then sent to the hiring manager who is the department head in the department that has the vacancy.
As an applicant, is it kosher to contact that department head? 
One the one hand, I am literally dying from anticipation from not knowing what may or may not come next - no timeline was given for the recruitment. 
On the other, contact might be perceived as impatient or uncouth. 
Really at a loss here.
title: Recruitment Etiquette
